3		1. I,	 Oleg	 Yurievych	 Alyoshin,	 of	 6th	Floor,	 17/52	 A	 Bohdana	 Khmelnytskoho	Street,	 Kyiv	 01054,	 Ukraine,	 set	 forth	 below	 my	 expert	 opinion	 on	 certain	issues	of	Ukrainian	law	in	connection	with	the	above	proceedings.			I. INTRODUCTION	2. I	have	previously	provided	one	expert	report	in	this	matter	dated	23	November	2021	(“my	First	Report”).	I	have	been	instructed	by	Fieldfisher	LLP	to	provide	this	Supplemental	Expert	Report	to	provide	the	Court	with	my	further	opinions	on	 certain	 points	 of	 disagreement	 between	 myself	 and	 Mr	 Beketov,	 the	Claimant’s	 expert,	 as	 appear	 from	 Mr	 Beketov’s	Eighth	Expert	 Report	("Beketov-8")	dated	23	November	2021	and	the	Joint	Report	of	the	Parties'	Experts	on	Ukrainian	Law	dated	11	February	2022	(the	"Joint	Report").	3. I	provided	details	of	my	experience	and	qualifications	in	my	First	Report.	For	completeness	I	record	that,	since	my	First	Report,	I	have	been	instructed	to	act	as	an	expert	on	Ukrainian	law	in	two	further	matters:	3.1. I	provided	an	expert	report	in	proceedings	in	the	English	High	Court	between	WWRT	Ltd	and	Mr	Kostyantin	Zhevago	(Claim	No.	CL-2021-000731),	on	the	instructions	of	RPC.	3.2. I	 also	 provided	 an	 expert	 report	 on	 behalf	 of	 Mr	 Kolomoisky	 in	proceedings	 brought	 by	 Privatbank	 in	 the	 District	 Court	 of	 Limassol,	instructed	by	K.	Chrysostomides	&	Co	LLC.		4. In	this	Supplemental	Report	I	address	only	those	matters	which	seem	to	me	to	be	of	significance	for	 the	 issues	 in	 this	 case.	 If	 I	 have	 not	 addressed	 any	particular	 matter	 reflected	 in	 the	Joint	 Report	here,	 it	 does	 not	 mean	 that	 I	agree	with	Mr	Beketov's	position	in	relation	to	such	matter.	For	the	avoidance	of	doubt,	I	maintain	the	opinions	expressed	in	my	First	Report	and	the	Joint	Report.	
C7/1/3
	
4		II. UKRAINIAN	LEGAL	SYSTEM	5. Mr	Beketov	accepts	that	the	Supreme	Court	judgments	are	a	source	of	law1	-	in	other	 words,	 that	 they	 have	 normative	 force	 for	 the	 purposes	 of	 the	interpretation	and	application	of	the	law	by	lower	courts.		There	seems	to	be	a	disagreement,	however,	as	to	the	degree	of	normative	force	which	they	have.	In	 Mr	 Beketov’s	 view,	 the	Supreme	 Court’s	 judgments	 are	 non-binding	 for	lower	courts	as	they	“need	only	be	'taken	into	account'	by	the	lower	courts	…	[and]	are	 treated	 as	 being	 of	 persuasive	 authority”.2	Mr	Beketov	 does	 not	explain	what	is	meant	by	“persuasive	authority”	in	a	civil	law	system.		6. Court	 practice	 consistently	 shows	 that	 decisions	 of	 the	 courts	 of	 lower	instances	are	only	viewed	as	lawful	if	they	take	into	account	legal	positions	set	out	in	the	resolutions	of	the	Supreme	Court.3	A	failure	to	consider	and,	where	relevant,	 follow	 the	 practice	 of	 the	 Supreme	 Court	 by	 the	 lower	 courts	 is	 a	ground	for	quashing	a	decision.4	On	this	basis,	the	Supreme	Court’s	decisions	can	properly	be	viewed	as	binding.		III. LIABILITY	IN	TORT		A. GENERAL	PRINCIPLES	7. Mr	Beketov	and	I	agree	as	to	the	basic	elements	of	a	tort	claim,	but	disagree	in	our	analysis	of	some	of	the	individual	elements,	as	well	as	on	some	points	of	general	principle

the	resolutions	of	the	Supreme	Court.3	A	failure	to	consider	and,	where	relevant,	 follow	 the	 practice	 of	 the	 Supreme	 Court	 by	 the	 lower	 courts	 is	 a	ground	for	quashing	a	decision.4	On	this	basis,	the	Supreme	Court’s	decisions	can	properly	be	viewed	as	binding.		III. LIABILITY	IN	TORT		A. GENERAL	PRINCIPLES	7. Mr	Beketov	and	I	agree	as	to	the	basic	elements	of	a	tort	claim,	but	disagree	in	our	analysis	of	some	of	the	individual	elements,	as	well	as	on	some	points	of	general	principle.	8. Regarding	general	principles,	Mr	Beketov	opines	that	Articles	3,	15	and	16	of	the	 Civil	 Code	 enshrine	 “as	 a	foundational	 principle”	 the	 right	 of	 victims	to	protect,	and	seek	redress	for	violations	of,	their	civil	rights	and	interests.5	He	also	concludes	that	this	right	or	principle	(which	he	describes	as	reflecting	“the		1	Beketov-8,	paragraph	25.	2	Joint	Report,	paragraph	4.1.	3	Resolution	of	the	Grand	Chamber	of	the	Supreme	Court	dated	18	March	2020	in	case	No.	464/104/16-ц,	paragraphs	46,	48,	Exhibit	AO2-1	page	9.	4	Civil	Procedure	Code,	Article	412(1),	(3),	Exhibit	AO2-2	page	9.	5	Beketov-8,	paragraph	67.	
C7/1/4
	
5		primacy	of	protecting	victims’	interests”)6	affects	the	courts’	consideration	of	tortious	claims	on	the	merits	in	that	courts	are	guided	by	this	principle	when	deciding	if	the	elements	of	a	tortious	claim	are	met.7		9. I	 disagree	 with	 these	 views.	 For	 the	 reasons	 given	 below,	 Mr	 Beketov’s	understanding	of	the	meaning	and	effect	of	the	right	to	judicial	protection	is	inaccurate	and	lacks	any	support	in	case	law	or	doctrine.		The	Articles	to	which	he	refers	are	of	a	procedural	nature	and	play	no	role	in	determining	whether	a	substantive	 tortious	 claim	 has	 been	 established	 under	 Article	 1166	 or	 any	other	relevant	provision.	10. I	will	start	by	giving	a	brief	explanation	of	the	nature	and	role	of	the	right	to	seek	judicial	protection	of	one’s	rights	and	interests	contained	in	Articles	3,	15	and	16	of	the	Civil	Code.8		11. Courts	consistently	adopt	the	view	that	the	right	to	seek	judicial	protection	under	Articles	3,	15	and	16	of	the	Civil	Code	derives	from	the	constitutional	right	 to	 a	 fair	 trial	 and	 access	 to	 justice.	 These	provisions	 are	 commonly	referred	to	in	conjunction	with	Article	6	of	the	European	Convention	on	Human	Rights	(the	“European	Convention”),	the	Constitution	and	rules	of	procedure9	that	 enshrine	 various	 procedural	 rights	 and	 principles.	 Below	 are	 a	 few	examples	 of	 cases	 where	 courts	 have	 invoked	 that	 principle	 to	 interpret	 or	apply	procedural	rules.		11.1. Extension	of	the	period	for	filing	an	appeal	against	a	court	judgement.	In	Bank	Khreshchatyk,	the	Supreme	Court	considered	an	appeal	against	a	lower	 court’s	 refusal	 to	 grant	 an	 extension	 for	 filing	 an	 appeal.	 The	Supreme	Court,	quashing	the	decision	of	the	lower	court,	held	as	follows:			6	Beketov-8,	paragraph	69.		7	Beketov-8,	paragraph	68.		8	I	will	translate	the	phrases	“sudoviy	zakhist”	and	“pravo	na	zakhist”	used	in	Articles	3,	15	and	16	of	the	Civil	Code	as	“judicial	protection”	and	a	“right	to	protection”	respectively.	Mr	Beketov	translates	them	as	“judicial	defence”	and	“right	to	a	defence”.	I	consider	my	translation	to	be	more	accurate	but	this	discrepancy	is	inconsequential.		9	Mr	Beketov	himself	refers	to	procedural	rules:	see	Beketov-8,	page	21,	footnote	20.		
C7/1/5
	
6		“Based	on	the	principle	of	the	rule	of	law,	the	provisions	of	Articles	21,	22	of	the	Constitution	of	Ukraine	on	the	inviolability	of	constitutional	rights	of	the	individual,	the	provisions	of	Article	6	of	the	Convention	for	the	Protection	of	Human	Rights	and	Fundamental	Freedoms	guaranteeing	a	person's	right	of	access	to	court	and	a	fair	hearing	of	their	case	by	a	court,	and	the	provisions	of	 Articles	 3,	 15	 of	 the	 Civil	 Code,	 and	Articles	 1,	 3,	 4	 of	 the	 Code	 of	 Civil	Procedure	concerning	a	right	of	a	person	for	a	judicial	protection	of	their	civil	right	and	interest,	it	follows	t

kraine	on	the	inviolability	of	constitutional	rights	of	the	individual,	the	provisions	of	Article	6	of	the	Convention	for	the	Protection	of	Human	Rights	and	Fundamental	Freedoms	guaranteeing	a	person's	right	of	access	to	court	and	a	fair	hearing	of	their	case	by	a	court,	and	the	provisions	of	 Articles	 3,	 15	 of	 the	 Civil	 Code,	 and	Articles	 1,	 3,	 4	 of	 the	 Code	 of	 Civil	Procedure	concerning	a	right	of	a	person	for	a	judicial	protection	of	their	civil	right	and	interest,	it	follows	that	the	right	of	a	person	to	judicial	protection	including	by	means	of	appealing	[judicial]	decisions,	is	a	priority.	[…]	The	 Court	 of	 Appeal,	 by	 refusing	 to	 open	 appeal	 proceedings,	 effectively	limited	the	applicant's	right	of	access	to	justice,	which	is	guaranteed	by	the	Constitution.”10		11.2. Relief	from	the	duty	to	pay	court	fees.	In	Romen	Correctional	Facility,11	the	Supreme	Court	held	that	a	refusal	to	exempt	the	applicant	from	payment	of	court	fees	due	to	financial	hardship	violated	the	claimant’s	right	to	protection	of	his	civil	rights.	11.3. Extension	of	the	period	for	a	judgment’s	enforcement	and	re-issuance	of	a	writ	for	execution.	In	Europartner	Finance,12	the	claimant	sought	an	extension	of	the	period	for	enforcing	a	court	judgment.	The	Supreme	Court	held	that,	on	the	facts	of	the	case,	denying	the	creditor’s	right	to	enforce	the	judgment	would	violate	its	right	to	judicial	protection	enshrined	in	Articles	3	and	15	of	the	Civil	Code.					12. I	am	not	aware	of	any	case	law	where	courts	have	relied	on	the	right	to	seek	judicial	protection	as	a	guide	when	deciding	the	dispute	on	the	merits.	To	the	contrary,	the	Supreme	Court	has	in	fact	held	that	the	right	has	no	autonomous	meaning	or	effect	from	the	perspective	of	substantive	law:	“Under	Article	15(1)	of	the	Civil	Code,	every	person	has	the	right	to	defend	his	or	her	civil	right	in	the	event	that	it	is	violated,	not	recognised,	or	disputed.	Thus,	within	the	meaning	of	the	law,	the	subjective	right	to	protection	is	a	legally	enshrined	possibility	for	a	person	to	use	legal	measures	to	restore	the	violated	right	and	terminate	actions	that	violate	the	right.		10	Ruling	of	the	Supreme	Court	dated	17	December	2012	in	case	No.	6-39663св14,	Exhibit	AO2-3	page	2;	see	also	Ruling	of	the	Supreme	Court	dated	27	November	2013	in	case	No.	6-39287св13,	Exhibit	AO2-4	page	2.		11	Resolution	of	the	Supreme	Court	dated	25	March	2020	in	case	No.	585/2683/19,	Exhibit	AO2-5	page	5.	12	Ruling	of	the	Supreme	Court	dated	11	October	2021	in	case	No.	2-1818/10,	Exhibit	AO2-6	page	3.	
C7/1/6
	
7		The	grounds	for	protection	under	Article	15	of	the	Civil	Code	are	not	specified,	but	 they	 are	 indicated	 in	 the	 rules	 of	 the	 Articles	governing	 the	 relevant	category	of	legal	relations.”13	13. In	other	words,	the	right	to	seek	judicial	protection	is	contingent	on	making	out	the	elements	of	a	claim	–	or,	as	the	Supreme	Court	has	stated,	“[t]he	substantive	aspect	of	the	protection	of	civil	rights	and	interests	lies	primarily	in	ascertaining	whether	a	person	has	such	a	right	or	interest	and	whether	it	has	been	violated.”14	14. Mr	 Beketov’s	 evidence	 confirms	 my	 view.	 In	 each	 of	 the	 cases	 to	 which	 he	refers,15	the	courts	relied	on	Articles	3,	15	or	16	of	the	Civil	Code	to	decide	procedural,	not	substantive,	matters.16			15. Consequently,	the	right	to	judicial	protection	is	not	relied	on	by	courts	when	considering	 tortious	 claims	 on	their	merits,	 and	 Ukrainian	 courts	 do	 not	prioritise	the	interests	of	the	(alleged)	victim	of	a	tort	over	the	interests	of	the	defendant.		16. Indeed,	to	deliberately	interpret	or	apply	the	law	in	a	way	which	favoured	a	claimant,	 just	 because	 of	 its	 status	 as	 a	 claimant,	 as	 Mr	 Beketov	in	 effect	proposes,	 would	breach	 the	 fundamental	principles	 of	 fairness	 and	 equality	and	would	be	 wrong	 in	 principle.	 Under	 Article	 2(1)	 of	 the	 Rules	 of	 Civil	Procedure:		“The	 objective	 of	 civil	 proceedings	 is	 the	 fair,	 impartial

the	interests	of	the	(alleged)	victim	of	a	tort	over	the	interests	of	the	defendant.		16. Indeed,	to	deliberately	interpret	or	apply	the	law	in	a	way	which	favoured	a	claimant,	 just	 because	 of	 its	 status	 as	 a	 claimant,	 as	 Mr	 Beketov	in	 effect	proposes,	 would	breach	 the	 fundamental	principles	 of	 fairness	 and	 equality	and	would	be	 wrong	 in	 principle.	 Under	 Article	 2(1)	 of	 the	 Rules	 of	 Civil	Procedure:		“The	 objective	 of	 civil	 proceedings	 is	 the	 fair,	 impartial	 and	 timely	consideration	 and	 resolution	 of	 civil	 cases	 to	 effectively	 protect	 violated,	unacknowledged	or	disputed	rights,	freedoms	or	interests	of	individuals,	the	rights	and	interests	of	legal	persons	and	the	interests	of	the	State.”17		13	Letter	of	the	Supreme	Court	"The	analysis	of	the	application	of	Article	16	of	the	Civil	Code”	dated	1	April	2014,	Exhibit	AO2-7	page	1.	14	Letter	of	the	Supreme	Court	"The	analysis	of	the	application	of	Article	16	of	the	Civil	Code”	dated	1	April	2014,	Exhibit	AO2-7	page	1.	15	Beketov-8,	footnote	21.	16	In	Resolution	of	the	Supreme	Court	dated	29	July	2021	in	case	No.	910/9752/16б	the	Supreme	Court	remitted	the	cases	for	a	retrial	because	of	a	failure	to	examine	the	material	facts,	Exhibit	AO2-8	pages	6,	8-10.	In	Resolution	of	the	Grand	Chamber	of	Supreme	Court	dated	15	May	2019	in	case	No.	717/2052/16-ц,	the	Supreme	Court	quashed	the	lower	court’s	decision	based	on	procedural	irregularities,	Exhibit	AO2-9	pages	9-10.	17	Civil	Procedure	Code,	Article	2(1),	Exhibit	AO2-2	page	1.	
C7/1/7
	
8		17. Mr	Beketov’s	view	that	the	courts	are	guided	by	considerations	of	protecting	victims’	interests	when	determining	a	tort	has	been	committed,	and	specifically	whether	harm	has	been	caused	to	the	claimant,	is	therefore	wrong	and	puts	the	matter	the	wrong	way	round.	The	true	position	is	that	the	claimant	has	a	right	to	have	its	claim	considered	by	the	court	and,	if	the	claim	is	proved,	the	right	to	an	 appropriate	 remedy.	 However,	whether	 the	 elements	 of	 the	 claim	 are	proved	or	not	must	be	determined	neutrally	and	objectively,	by	reference	to	the	 facts	 and	 the	 applicable	 rules	 of	 substantive	 law,	 and	 without	 any	assumption	 that	 the	 claimant	 has	 suffered	 harm	 or	 that	 any	 of	 the	 other	elements	of	the	claim	are	satisfied.	After	all,	it	is	not	until	all	the	elements	of	a	claim	are	proved	that	the	claimant	can	be	considered	a	“victim”	of	a	tort	with	substantive	rights	that	require	protection	or	restoration.	B. HARM	(1) Principles	relevant	for	assessing	harm			18. All	 experts	 agree	 that	 harm	 is	 one	 of	 the	 elements	 of	 a	tortious	 claim.18	However,	 there	 is	 disagreement	 as	 to	 how	 Ukrainian	 courts	 go	 about	determining	the	existence	and	amount	of	recoverable	harm.		19. While	 the	 harm	 that	 the	 claimant	 has	 suffered	 is	 a	 question	 of	 fact,	 certain	principles	 and	 limitations	 do	 apply	when	 deciding	 the	 amount	 that	 is	ultimately	recoverable.	In	particular,	as	I	have	explained,	the	mere	infliction	of	harm	is	insufficient	for	giving	rise	to	tortious	liability.	Harm	is	not	recoverable	when	it	is	caused	by	acts	that	are	not	unlawful	as	a	matter	of	civil	law;	or	when	the	defendant’s	unlawful	act	has	not	directly	caused	the	relevant	harm.19	The	defendant’s	liability	arises	only	when	he	violates	a	duty	to	act	or	not	to	act	in	a	certain	way	and	that	unlawful	act	directly	causes	the	harm	that	is	the	subject	of	the	claim.20	The	court	therefore	has	to	identify	and	quantify	the	harm	which	directly	resulted	from	the	defendant's	unlawful	act	or	omission.			18	Joint	Report,	paragraph	22.1.		19	Alyoshin-1,	paragraph	194.		20	Alyoshin-1,	paragraphs	186-193;	250-252.	
C7/1/8
	
9		20. It	should	also	be	emphasised	that	the	identification	and	quantification	of	harm	are	governed	by	express	statutory	rules.	I	disagree	with	Mr	Beketov	who	seems	to	be	of	the	view	that	courts	may	determine	the	amount	of	recoverable	harm	based	on	general	principles	such	as	reasonableness

quantify	the	harm	which	directly	resulted	from	the	defendant's	unlawful	act	or	omission.			18	Joint	Report,	paragraph	22.1.		19	Alyoshin-1,	paragraph	194.		20	Alyoshin-1,	paragraphs	186-193;	250-252.	
C7/1/8
	
9		20. It	should	also	be	emphasised	that	the	identification	and	quantification	of	harm	are	governed	by	express	statutory	rules.	I	disagree	with	Mr	Beketov	who	seems	to	be	of	the	view	that	courts	may	determine	the	amount	of	recoverable	harm	based	on	general	principles	such	as	reasonableness,	good	faith	or	fairness.21	This	 is	 not	 correct.	I	 am	 not	aware	 of	 any	 cases	 where	 courts	 have	applied	solely	the	general	principles	such	as	reasonableness,	good	faith	or	fairness	to	determine	the	amount	of	non-contractual	(tort)	damages.	Mr	Beketov	does	not	cite	any	such	cases	either.	There	are	specific	rules	governing	causation	and	the	assessment	 of	 damages,22	and	 while	 those	 rules	 are	 naturally	informed	 by	general	 concepts	 of	 fairness	 and	 reasonableness,	such	concepts	 have	 no	independent	 application	 and	 cannot	 be	 invoked	 directly	 to	 increase	 or	decrease	 the	 amount	 of	 recoverable	 compensation	for	 tortious	 loss	in	 a	particular	case.		21. Mr	Beketov	also	refers	to	a	so-called	principle	of	“full	compensation”,	which	he	says	 is	 reflected	 in	 Articles	 22(3),	 1166(1)	 and	 1192(1)	 of	 the	 Civil	 Code,23	whereby	a	victim	must	be	fully	compensated	for	its	losses24	including,	where	relevant,	lost	profits	in	the	form	of	compound	interest.25	It	seems	that,	in	Mr	Beketov’s	 opinion,	 this	supposed	principle	 has	 an	 autonomous	 effect	 and	Ukrainian	courts	must	be	guided	by	it26	in	addition	to	the	applicable	rules	of	causation	and	quantification.	Thus	Mr	Beketov	says	that:	“the	 quantification	 of	 the	 Bank’s	 loss	 resulting	 from	 the	 Misappropriation,	including	any	reduction	to	that	loss	by	the	value	of	assets	transferred	to	the	Bank	in	purported	repayment	of	the	Relevant/Intermediary	Loans,	would	fall	to	be	assessed	as	a	matter	of	fact	(both	causation	and	quantification	of	harm		21	Beketov-8,	paragraphs	134,	139.	22	For	instance,	the	law	allows	the	claimant	a	contributory	negligence	defence,	and	courts	may	reduce	the	amount	of	recoverable	harm	accordingly:	Civil	Code,	Article	1193(1)-(2),	Exhibit	AO2-10	page	4. Or	court	may	 also	 reduce	 the	 amount	 of	 recoverable	 harm	 when	 a	 claimant	 has	 failed	 to	 mitigate	 its	 losses:	Resolution	 of	 the	 Supreme	 Court	 dated	 24	 February	 2021	in	 case	 No.	904/982/19,	paragraphs	 31-33,	Exhibit	AO2-11	page	9;	paragraph	40,	page	10;	paragraphs	60-66,	pages	12-13.			23	Beketov-8,	paragraph	146.	24	Beketov-8,	paragraph	135.			25	Beketov-8,	paragraph	332.		26	Beketov-8,	paragraph	69	(“The	primacy	of	protecting	victims’	interests	is	[…]	reflected	in	the	principle	of	full	compensation”);	paragraph	68	(“When	Ukrainian	courts	construe	the	elements	of	liability	under	Article	1166,	including	consideration	of	whether	harm	has	been	caused	as	a	matter	of	fact,	they	are	guided	by	the	overarching	objective	of	protecting	the	victim’s	interests”).		
C7/1/9
	
10		are	 matters	 of	 fact	 under	 Ukrainian	 law	 […])	 and	 in	 accordance	 with	 the	general	rules	regarding	damages	set	out	in	Article	22	of	the	Civil	Code	([…]),	including	the	principle	that	the	Bank	is	entitled	to	be	fully	compensated	for	its	loss	caused	by	the	Defendants’	tortious	conduct.”27	22. I	 disagree	 with	 Mr	 Beketov.	 In	 my	 opinion,	 Ukrainian	 tort	 law	 does	 not	recognise	an	autonomous	and	overriding	principle	of	“full	compensation”,	at	least	 one	 which	 would	 have	 the	 effect	 of	 increasing	 the	 recoverable	compensation	above	the	amount	which	would	result	from	the	application	of	the	ordinary	rules	governing	the	assessment	of	damages	and	the	compensatory	character	of	civil-law	liability.		23.
